name: Skriðuklaustur - Centre of Culture & History
description: Skriðuklaustur stands as one of East Iceland's most significant cultural and historical sites, combining archaeological remains of Iceland's only Augustinian monastery with the beautifully preserved home of Iceland's internationally acclaimed author Gunnar Gunnarsson (1889-1975), creating a unique destination where medieval monastic history, literary heritage, contemporary art, and ongoing archaeological research converge in a stunning setting along the banks of the Lagarfljót river. The monastery ruins date to 1493 when they were founded by Jón ríki Þorsteinsson and operated until Iceland's Reformation in 1550 forced the dissolution of all Catholic religious institutions—making this 57-year period the entire span of monastic life in Iceland. Archaeological excavations begun in 2002 have revealed fascinating details about this lost world: the monastery layout including church, chapter house, dormitory, and hospital where monks cared for the sick and poor; artifacts including religious objects, medical implements, and everyday tools; and evidence of how Icelandic monks adapted continental monastic traditions to Iceland's unique environment. The excavations remain ongoing, and visitors can observe active archaeological work during summer months, with walkways and interpretive signage explaining findings. The Writer's House (Gunnarshús), completed in 1939, represents author Gunnar Gunnarsson's vision of an ideal home after years of literary success in Denmark where he wrote in Danish before returning to his Icelandic roots.
